												A refinement of part 2, which I liked more but which I also did not play on Steam, so you're getting a recommendation of this and not that. The gameplay is standard Assassin's Creed stuff with a few additions that make it much easier, it's up to you whether that's a good or bad thing. I found a lot of the upgrade systems to be largely unecessary and mostly just busywork. If you play it stealthy like you're supposed to you won't need more powerful weapons and armor. And as long as you learn the combat you can get by with anything. The dialogue is not always great but at least the overall story is not insufferably bad. Requiescat in pace, videogioch.

Posted: November 29, 2013
												A sequel to AC2, you could easily say that this is AC2 again but extending the storyline further with some better closure than the previous game delivered (It's basically AC2's second half). It picks up right where AC2 ends and continues on with more funtimes and stuff to do. There are new improvements here to the gameplay, graphics, and the gigantic city of Rome is much larger and unique than any other location in the previous games. It's slightly bigger than its predecessor, and it adds multiplayer (which probably nobody plays anymore) as well. If you want innovation, there isn't much here. But if you enjoyed AC2 and want to keep running with that, this is the game for you.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												7/10Overall not a bad expansion, Ezio is a likeable protagonist though the story is a little dull and feels a bit drawn out and padded with too many side quests. If you're looking for more ACII then this will not disappoint.++ Builds on the same solid gameplay as ACII+Some interesting developments in Desmonds story line (Main reason I played this in the first place)+Leonardo's warmachines are a blast+/- Lots of new mechanics, to the point that at times it feels like there are too many.+/- Tons of side missions (Played 60 hours and didn't even come close to doing them all). Good if you want to spend lots of time playing the game but they feel shallow and tacked on at times.---"Why would you jump that way Ezio!?!  Of course I don't want you to jump to your death, there's a ledge right there, wouldn't you like to grab it instead?!"-Never get to use Leonardo's warmachines outside of their individual missions!-Would REALLY like if the achievements showed in Steam! (Not the games fault obviously).-Some missions have vague objectives where you'll keep failing and not really know why.Definitely recommend if you enjoyed ACII, just don't expect any ground breaking changes.

Posted: January 25, 2015
												Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood (henceforth referred to as AC:B) is the third title in the Assassin's Creed series. Chronologically taking place after AC2, this is a nice sequel. Admittedly the numerous graphical glitches (ground not loading, birds stretching into the sky, enemies sliding on hills) are distracting and do take you out of the moment. The story is gripping, and the addition of heavy weapons is a nice touch. However, AC:B fails in the respect of convenience: you have to buy the stores yourself in order for them to sell you things, and you often need quite a bit of money to do that. Frankly they should have not included that facet, it was the worst part of the game. The combat was much to easy, AC1 had the right idea in preventing you from using the counter move until halfway through the game, forcing you to dodge and such. Despite this, I still reccomend this game.

Posted: December 29, 2011
												The Single Player is not much more than Assassin's Creed 2, just one or two new ways to kill people or get around the city, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but any gripes with the series so far probably haven't been addressed with this installment, and what people have liked about the series is still in the game.  My favorite aspect of Brotherhood was the multiplayer.  I personally haven't played any game that had this style of gameplay, so it was "fresh" so to say, something new to learn, new mechanics to wrap my head around and master, a different way to use the mechanics we were given in single player.  I greatly enjoyed the way the multiplayer emulated the feeling that the original assassin's creed created when it first released, which was the feeling of being an assassin, which I personally haven't felt since AC 1 was released.

Posted: March 20, 2011
												A must have for any Assassin's Creed fan!The game adds substantial new content and improvements to make it worth the full price. While some people, myself included. Thought before launch that it would simply be a rehash of AsC 2 with little new content in terms of the singleplayer. We have definitely been proven wrong.This game is also a proper PC port with vastly upgraded graphics in comparison to AsC-B on consoles. Proper UI, HUD and menus and for the first time in a while, the ability to play offline (yes, that's right the DRM that was so hated in AsC 2 is now gone!)The multiplayer is extremely fun and while some might say it bears resemblence to the Ship, the similarities are small, if any at all. At most one could say it was inspired by the Ship.The multiplayer mechanics work well and leave a lot of room for player skill to play a role. There is also a decent variety of modes, all of which provide different feel and play tactics.All in all the best AsC to date!

Posted: February 8, 2014
												Brotherhood picks up the story exactly (literally!) when AC2 left it. And I must say, I'm pretty amazed by what the producers did with this game. The combat system is much better now, with introduction of killing streaks, but also with stronger and more difficult enemies. To get 100% in the mission, you have to also do some additional objectives (which sometimes are quite troublesome!). The city of Rome is an amazingly big area, unlike anything you have seen in the previous games. Characters are very interesting and the whole storyline is quite good (though, not as good as in AC2 in my opinion). Also, there are multitudes of additional missions and content, so finishing the entire game takes tremendeous amount of time. All in all, this game will definitely not dissapoint you so I can recommend it to anyone that loves AC.Actually, after playing AC:R, AC3 and AC4, I must say that if you love AC franchise, that would be the last game I would recommend to play, if you don't want a huge letdown.

												While the Assassin's Creed series isn't exactly shining at the time that I write this, this game is, and likely always will be, my favorite Assassin's Creed game and one of my favorite games of all time. Posted: April 21, 2011
												This game is great: it runs very smoothly and efficiently, the plot is well developed, and the freerunning is a little less linear or obvious now. There are some zones that you navigate like a 3-dimmensional maze. Combat is a lot more fluid and you can kill many more units at once, so there are now much larger battles in place.The plot is well-written, and, as with the environments, attention was taken on details-- at least until about 60% synched. I'm not spoiling anything, but just know that the game is about 90% complete when it gets to about 60%, and you can't access any more of the world (shops, training, etc.) once you get to this point. (With broken armor it made this part incredibly hard.)The multiplayer is also very well done. It's pretty unique to the market, even in its execution: it's a game where not only do you match your abilities versus your opponents, but your ability to play mind-games as well. Incredibly well done.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												Awesome follow up to AC2.  Plenty of stuff to do after you've done the main quest, including assassinations, training your own apprentices, rebuilding parts of Rome, investing in small businesses and just soaking up the amazing atmosphere of Renaissance Italy!  It will take you well over 100 hours of gameplay to 100% complete (I have only about half of this because my game client used to glitch out and not count hours).  Anyway I would 100% recommend this game if you have previously played AC2, otherwise you will have no clue about what is going on when you come to start.  Graphics - 9/10Sound - 9/10Story - 6/10Gameplay - 10/10Sound - 10/10

												The sequel to ACII didn't disappoint, Brotherhood was really fun to play. The story continues the fight against the Borgia and their Templar agents in Rome, Ezio takes it upon himself to lead the Assassin Order as they try to free Rome from their influence. This was nicely portrayed as you rebuild your Assassin Order while crippling Templar presence. The story was shorter than the previous game, but it was still very well made and packed with intriguing characters.The gameplay didn‚Äôt change much from ACII, but did add some entertaining side missions like liberating sectors of Rome from Borgia oppression, further develop the city‚Äôs economy and various assassination contracts. Ezio develops his leadership skills while training recruits and managing the Order, this also allows the ability to call assassins as backup or send them on mission across Europe.The graphics and animations are amazing, the streets, the architecture and monuments and landmarks of Rome are breathtaking and really add to the game‚Äôs immersion. The soundtrack itself adds to this, combining some old songs with new ones, really good work.Definately a game worth buying and a great addition to the series.

												Very much an iteration on Assassin's Creed II, but not necessarily in a bad way. The combat and movement of Ezio feels more fluid and refined, and so does everything else in this sequel.Rome is a fantastic location with tons of unique scenery and history. 												The second Assassin's Creed title I've played.  The core mechanics remain the same, which in most cases is a mixed blessing. Posted: July 17, 2013
												I thought I'd re-recommend some games due to how poorly written and dumb my old recommendations were.The Assassin's Creed series has always been a great series (with a few exceptions ;3), and its games often are amazing and enjoyable, with breathtaking scenery and amazing gameplay: this one is no exception.Assassin's Creed Brotherhood consists of a fairly long storyline, filled with enjoyable and interesting missions.  Playing in the beautiful city of Roma as Ezio Auditore is a great experience, and the city allows for much adventure and open world exploration outside of the storyline.  In fact, there are multiple stories you can follow, for instance there is a free addition you can download where you play a story that takes place shortly after the main adventure.  The game also intertwines with historical places, facts, and people, such as the Borgias.  The main antagonist is Cesare Borgia, a well-developed and historically-based character.  The storyline shows how you attack him from various directions and slowly take back the city.  This installment of the series introduces a new concept: Assassin Recruits.  The game allows you to pick up fellow citizens and teach them in the ways of the assassin, and throughout the story you can call upon them to help you.  In general, this can lead to many fun battles: I personally enjoyed running around and attracting as many guards as possible, then just call in fellow assassins and murder them all. >:DThe multiplayer mode of this game is great.  To run around and attack others while being chased yourself in a small area is so much fun, and there are all sorts of gimmicks and hiding places you can use to make chases and escapes even more exhilirating.  However, it can be difficult to get a multiplayer game going, since there aren't often many people on the network.  If you manage to get a game though, stay in it and play around for a while, you'lll unlock new bonuses and rewards as you level up from playing.One last thing to note about this game is the enviornment.  I mentioned before that the game takes place in Roma, and in case you didn't know, Rome is a pretty vast and beautiful place. :P  You don't play through Rome during its days of glory, but long after when many of its structures are in ruins and the Borgia have complete control and power over the city.  As you gain wealth and status in the city (usually from not-so friendly ways... protip: Borgia Towers are strangely very flammable), you can repair old buildings, buy renown places such as the Coliseum and the Pantheon and gain the trust of nearby factions such as theives and courtesans.  In general, the envoirnment is very large yet extremely detailed and gorgeous.  With so much to do in the city, oftentimes you may set out to go get something done but find yourself trying to kill a Borgia Captain and igniting a tower hours later.In general, the game is amazing.  As I said in my previous 2-word review: "Awesome shtuff."

												Another good installment of AC.  8/10.  Picks up after AC 2, with Ezio again a few years after AC 2 took place.  Focused solely in Rome with 4 areas that unlock as you progress.  The story was interesting.  Ezio pulls together the 3 factions to defat a common enemy, and ends with a decent addition to the lore.  Graphics look good.  Combat is the same as usual.  Entertaining but frustrating.  Running through streets will enevitibly result in you running up a wall you didn't intend to, or hoping up on a barrel killing your progress in timed missions.  The camera will hide behind a tree during a battle with multiple enemies.  If Ubisoft could solve these issues this series would be a 9 or a 10 for me, but as of AC 4, they are still present.  I liked the economic twist they added in this installment. Posted: October 29, 2014
												Brotherhood starts off immediately where the previous game left off. When I say this, I really mean you start in the exact spot, wearing the same gear you were at the end of the previous game. The story picks up right away and continues to entice.This game, while different in various ways, keeps the same essence of the last game. You explore Roma during the Borgia reign of the early 16th century. This allows for, like all the games, some splendid views and the ability to truly appreiciate the thought and effort put into the design of the city and surrounding areas plus the attention to detail that I have come to enjoy and appreiciate. There is a lot to do in this game. The added Economics allows for lots of money to be made and spent in Roma. This just builds on the ability in the previous game to earn and spend money and puts that to work on a grander scale. The added abilities, weapons, and use of the syncing percentage really shine in this game. I found myself using the crossbow alot more than I thought I would and not just out of neccesity but actual enjoyment. Leveling up you own assassins within your guild and using them in various ways allowed for more interesting encounters with enemies and missions. Having missions have an optional objectives/constraints to get a sync percentage made had me retrying missions all the time to achieve that percentage. It made the replay value, for even the first time through, appealing and challenging. Overall, if you like the series and played the games up until this point, continue to do so. You won't be disappointed.

Posted: December 3, 2014
												Okay, all Assassin's Creeds have the same basic idea, but they are different usually. But, AC: Brotherhood and AC II are VERY similar in many respects, and since I haven't played them for awhile, I am literally copy-pasting the same review to both of them because I can't remember all the little things that are different, because really, they are very similar. So here we go:I love the Assassin's Creed series. I played the first AC about seven years ago, and I played it nonstop. The basic idea of AC is that you are and assassin, and you have a city as your assassination-playground, usually multiple locations. You start the game as Desmond, a guy who uses a machine called the Animus to shoot back in time to his ancestors' history. This is accomplished from the Animus being able to use his mind as a channel for those ancestors' memories. Then, you are his ancestor, an assassin. and you have to kill things. The story is usually deep and intriguing, and it brings you along, and the gameplay of it is awesome too. And then you can just do random things as sidequests, usually pickpocketing, or another assassination target, stuff like that. You have two profiles: Low profile, where you don't draw attention, and just push past people, or walk. Then High profile, by holding right trigger, where then you start running and you can parkour, fight, shove through people, and sprint. The combat is fun, and the sneaky-assassinating is satisfying. There's some flaws, but Brotherhood and AC II are probably the best out of this series. Would recommend anybody to try.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												Assassin's Creed Brotherhood is in my opinion, the best Assassin's Creed game out there.Let me tell you why.The story picks up right after Assassins Creed II's ending, so I can't really talk much about what it happens in it, but what I can say is that Desmond finds himself in Monteriggioni reliving the rest of the memories of his ancestor Ezio Auditore da Firenze to look for clues as to where is the Apple of Eden, an ancient artifact from an advanced civilization of old.Ezio's story itself also takes place right after the ending of Assassins Creed II, but to keep it spoiler free, all I can tell is that Ezio now finds himself in Rome trying to take on The Borgia family's tyranny while building his own Assassin Brotherhood.From this little synopsis of the plot you can pretty much tell the most important draw fromt he game, it doesn't feel 100% new in it's assassin story. It just expands upon Ezio's story in AC II. Plus the game doesn't do many things differently from AC II in terms of presentation or even core gameplay, BUT it does add many other good things.For instance, the game adds dual wielding to some weapons, which removes the tediousness of constantly having to switch weapons using the weapon wheel to change weapons. Not only that, but now you can customize the d-pad weapon shortcuts. The game also adds a killstreak feature which allows you to make chain kills in combat, while it's fun to use, it makes the combat a little too easy. The game adds new weapons like: The crossbow or the Poison Darts, which offer new approaches to each situation that's presented to you. Another feature is that you can now use horses everywhere in the city of Rome, making navigation much faster. Another great feature is that now you can exit the Animus at any time to play as Desmond and interact with your crew and surroundings, and I must admit that it comes close to the the great moments as Desmond from AC I, disgracely roaming in Monteriggioni is timed and you cannot do much. But seeing how Monteriggioni has aged is considerably interesting.Now the main gameplay feature from Brotherhood is that you can now recruit Assassins into your own Brotherhood, which can aid you in battle or on assasinations. This assassins can be sent on missions for experience and other rewards until they reach the Asassin rank. This system can essentially bring more hours of gameplay and enjoyment into the game. The last system added unto the game is the Rome renovation system, in which you can invest on locales from Rome after you've eliminated Borgia controll, which can give you money in return. While similar to the Monteriggioni system from AC II it does add some more depth to it.The only issue I have from all of this is that there are far too many things to do in the game eventually leaving you overwhelmed by all the choices.The story is presented in the same way as AC II, while adding the much needed memory replay option and some interesting optional objectives to get cheats or costumes for your character.Another feature from this game is a multiplayer component, which consists in assassinating other players while trying not to be assasinated. I couldn't really check it out because of the following issue, THE COMMUNITY IS BASICALLY DEAD. It is pretty much impossible to play a good MP match nowadays because of the lack of dedicated servers or an active community to play with.Overall, Assassin's Creed Brotherhood does everything that Assassin's Creed II did right, while at the same time adding new content to the game. This is a must play for every AC fan out there and a worthwhile check to everyone else.If you are not a big fan of AC get it on sale at least but check it out at least once in your life.PC PORT REPORT: ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• YOU UPLAY I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING HATE YOU. Same issues with AC I though. Poor controls that can be rebindable, so if you plan on checking this game out I recommend getting a controller compatible with a PC beforehand. If you have the console version I recommend staying away from this PC port because it doesn't add anything worthwhile to the core game.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												Overall still recommendable though the game is not without its minor and major flaws.The PC controls are inexplicably worse from part 2. A real mystery because they improved mucho between AC1 and AC2 and then in Brotherhood it's worse again (like the req to hit 'enter' instead of 'space' on many confirmation dialogues or how 'TAB' opens the map but does not close it again... WTF). The story did not grab me as much as part 2. Leo Da Vinci added a nice touch in AC2 that was sorely missing in Brotherhood. Many story and optional missions were quite grindy and drawn out. I'm not a fan of the lengthy escorts or tailing missions of which there seemed to be too many. There was also too much trial & error, in part due to the absence of mission critical info,  which led to IMHO unnecessary repetition due to the console checkpoint save system.I liked the 15th/16th century depiction of Rome though. The atmosphere and ambience was great. The story, while not stellar, was still motivating enough to make me keep playing and finishing the game. So overall it gets a thumbs up but I'd warn anyone to be prepared to lose some hair over the game's annoyances that are mostly owed to the game's console heritage.

Posted: November 22, 2014
												Great game! Felt short compared to Assassin's Creed 2, but still great. Only issue I've had is that the video tends to lag in the cutscenes so you'll hear things happen before seeing them, but the gameplay is lag free.Running on:Macbook Pro 15inch Mid-2010OS X 10.8.52.66 GHz Intel Core i78GB RAM 1067 MHz DDR3NVIDIA GeForce GT 330M 512 MBTip:If you're a Mac user and download AC Brotherhood, you may find that it doesn't work when you first launch it. All you need to do is the following:1. Go to /Library/Application Support/Steam/SteamApps/common/2. Go into the AC2 folder (assuming you have already bought AC2) and copy the Ubisoft Game Launcher from the Ubisoft folder.3. Go into the AC Brotherhood folder and replaced the Ubisoft Game Launcher in there with the version from the AC2 folder.I did this and it works fine.

Posted: November 16, 2014
A continuation from ACII.Elements from ACII are carried to this game and the story continues with a little more of everything. This time around, the player feels more included in the Assassin band because you could send in a team at your command. The story is as interesting as ACII if not a little less, because the game tries to answer everyone's questions, both the audience and Ezio's. There are a few more gadgets and a brotherhood, otherwise that is it. The gameplay is basically the same as in ACII. By the end of ACII, Ezio got a bit comfortable, but right from the beginning of this game, it is clear that there are other powers out there that are constantly uprising. As usual, the game design is beautiful. The city of Italy has a lot to take in with many areas to explore. The missions are roughly the same as in ACII, but there are a few new ones that were refreshing. This iteration of the series was not as amazing as ACII, but was still a fun game to experience.The StrengthsThe developers played it a bit safe by just using the same formula from the previous game. I enjoyed the sense of 'Brotherhood' when interaction with the assassin family in the game. I thought that the addition of the crossbow was awesome, and on top of that the arrow storm proved to be very useful in many situations that I encountered.The LimitationsAlthough there was a good amount of features added to the game, I did not get the same sense of awe throughout the game.

Posted: November 18, 2014
												Assassin's Creed Brotherhood adalah lanjutan kisah Desmond yang kembali meneruskan ingatan Ezio Auditore yang pindah ke Roma untuk membebaskan Roma dari kekuasaan keluarga Borgia.Cerita (8/10)Lanjutan AC II tentang Ezio yang membebaskan kota Roma dari kekuasaan kekuasaan Borgia, setelah sebelumnya pada AC II, Rodrigo Borgia kabur dari Ezio di Vatikan. Terkesan seperti memperpanjang AC II, AC Brotherhood bertujuan untuk mendapatkan lokasi Piece of Eden. Twist paling menarik ada pada endingnya yang membuat kisah Desmond makin penasaran.Gameplay (9/10)AC Brotherhood memberikan beberapa fitur baru setelah AC II. Salah satu yang paling menarik adalah adanya Assassin Recruit. Dengan fitur ini, Ezio tidak perlu menyerang semua pasukan sendirian. Cukup dekati pasukan sebelum menyadari keberadaannya, Ezio cukup beri aba2 dan semua pasukan mati ditikam / dipanah. Tidak perlu bertarung &  dikeroyok sendirian seperti sebelumnya.Grafis (8/10)Perbaikan grafis paling terlihat dari desain karakter & tekstur yang lebih detil dan proporsional dari AC II yang masih terkesan kasar & membuat Desmond terlihat gemuk. Hahaha.

Posted: December 10, 2013
												While the changes are not as drastic as the ones from the first Assassin's Creed to the second,Brotherhood goes a nice way to improve upon the already extremely solid formula cemented by its predecessor.Combat is made quicker and flashier through the ability to use both meele and long-range weapons together and the introduction of a chain-kill mechanic. The Assassin recruits create a simple, yet surprisingly engaging past time that pays off big in the long run and for those who enjoyed renovating Ezio's villa in the last game, there is now the entirity of Rome to do as you please with. Even with all this, there is no doubt that this does feel like "Assassin's Creed 2: 2", but when the changes that are there build so well upon the last game all the same, one can't really complain.

Posted: January 3, 2013
												I can say without hesitation that Brotherhood is easily the best installment out of the entire Assassin's Creed franchise. Ubisoft Montreal took the massive breakthrough that was AC2's gameplay and refined it, expanded it, and built on top of it - giving the player an experience with an immense amount of depth and ceaseless enjoyment. While some might say that this game was more "expansion" than a true release the continuation of Ezio Auditore's storyline did wonders for the character, the historical time period, and the AC universe in general.Brotherhood was also the first title in the series to feature an online multiplayer that not only amazed us with its addictiveness but also really challenged us - rewarding players for being patient and clever instead of relentless and clumsy.

Posted: November 7, 2014
												I originally skipped this AC game since I felt it didn't wrap the Ezio storyline when it was released, and I only got it since it was on special.Given that I payed little for it, I felt that I got my money's worth. This game doesn't add much to the AC story, but Ezio is one of the coolest assassins in the franchise and it was a blast to play through another adventure as him.The gameplay of AC2 before it were polished to a tee in this game, and the new features allowing you to hire assassins, level them up, and call them in for assists was pretty cool. Posted: October 29, 2014
												Brotherhood starts off immediately where the previous game left off. When I say this, I really mean you start in the exact spot, wearing the same gear you were at the end of the previous game. The story picks up right away and continues to entice.This game, while different in various ways, keeps the same essence of the last game. You explore Roma during the Borgia reign of the early 16th century. This allows for, like all the games, some splendid views and the ability to truly appreiciate the thought and effort put into the design of the city and surrounding areas plus the attention to detail that I have come to enjoy and appreiciate. There is a lot to do in this game. The added Economics allows for lots of money to be made and spent in Roma. This just builds on the ability in the previous game to earn and spend money and puts that to work on a grander scale. The added abilities, weapons, and use of the syncing percentage really shine in this game. I found myself using the crossbow alot more than I thought I would and not just out of neccesity but actual enjoyment. Leveling up you own assassins within your guild and using them in various ways allowed for more interesting encounters with enemies and missions. Having missions have an optional objectives/constraints to get a sync percentage made had me retrying missions all the time to achieve that percentage. It made the replay value, for even the first time through, appealing and challenging. Overall, if you like the series and played the games up until this point, continue to do so. You won't be disappointed.

Posted: March 31, 2015
												I played ACB immediately after AC2, and the game was way above what I had expected. Nearly all good parts of AC2 were kept and some flows were improved too(especially the combot execution system). The Assassin recruit system is very awesome, I litearally yelled when I used a recruit to easily assassinate my mission target. The recruits provide a lot of help during combat and I sometimes think that  they are better assasins than me. However, the game seriously lacks custimization for the recruits, which is very disappointing. All recruits look pretty much the same once they reach max level. This is very different from the trailer where Ezio have different looking recruits holding different weapons on his side. The main storyline is pretty short compared to that of AC2. In order to compensate this, ACB has a ridicuously large amount of side missions for players to experience, although some are not that fun to play. Assasinating in ACB is easier compared to AC2 as players can easily use the crossbow and hidden balde poison to kill targets from distance without being detected. Although you can see I am criticizing the game from different angles, I have to say, ACB is definitly a good game that every AC fan should consider buying, as it has too much good parts that I can't explain simply in this review.
